commit_message:
Karbor: update the $PROJECTS variable of the job definition

Add the project trove to the $PROJECTS variable in the job
definition karbor.yaml. To fix the erorr about cloning trove
when the trove service is enable[1].

[1]https://review.openstack.org/#/c/480204/

Change-Id: Icf6397bae939d524c0f9bf249677a7f8bd6e06f8

commit_message:
Fix wrong port bindings of HA router interfaces

The disruption of the overlay network will cause the slave node of a HA
router to be promoted as master but the master node will not be degraded
to slave. If the newly promoted master node is degraded to slave after
the network is restored, the router interface still points to the host
where the slave node resides.

This patch fixes this problem by updating port bindings of the router
interfaces to the host whose ha_state is active.

Closes-Bug: #1636466
Change-Id: If11de63c08a2aa4902498a18b4dc878d71d6dcaf
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/09/390509/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
WIP "Do not merge" multiattach code, review only

This patch is not meant for merging.

Please Note:

1. Parent patch-set are:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/271047/
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/267587/

Nova side patch:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/466184/1

2. Rebased off mitaka

3. This patch is only for reviewing possible basis of implementing
multiattach functionality. Based on dicussion on this approach in
"#openstack-meeting-cp" IRC channel it may evolve

4. Rebasing to Ocata is in progress

Change-Id: Ie16f8f04638fbd9e2c820ef30785f5846a139de9

subject: Enable lease-update to update start/end time with date
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-06-05 10:54:26.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-blazarclient/commit/906592b5875a07d3963fdb70033ed47e6f8d66ea', 'message': "Enable lease-update to update start/end time with date

lease-update CLI only accepts time delta to update start_time
or end_time of leases. It's hard to specify a specific date as
its argument since users need to caluclate the time delta
between previous start/end time and the specific date.

This patch enables users to use a specific date for its
arguments.

Change-Id: I5044213656a22ffa99d96f3d2f3f92752da1b6e9
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2017-06-05 13:40:49.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-blazarclient/commit/15c888278badc19685d40fde7e9e90a362c1d2f8', 'message': 'Enable lease-update to update start/end time with date

lease-update CLI only accepts time delta to update start_time
or end_time of leases. It's hard for users to specify a specific
date as its argument since users need to caluclate the time delta
between the previous start/end time and the new date.

This patch enables users to update leases with date format
like --end-date "2017-06-05 17:15".

Change-Id: I5044213656a22ffa99d96f3d2f3f92752da1b6e9

commit_message:
Enable lease-update to update start/end time with date

lease-update CLI only accepts time delta to update start_time
or end_time of leases. It's hard for users to specify a specific
date as its argument since users need to caluclate the time delta
between the previous start/end time and the new date.

This patch enables users to update leases with date format
like --end-date "2017-06-05 17:15".

Change-Id: I5044213656a22ffa99d96f3d2f3f92752da1b6e9

commit_message:
Pause resource cleanup

When pause_teardown flag in tempest.conf is set to True a pdb breakpoint
is added to tearDown and tearDownClass methods in test.py.
This allows to pause cleaning resources process, so that, used resources
can be examined. Closer examination of used resources may lead to faster
debugging.

Change-Id: I09b7721e64cda161289f915d30888ec54bbed821
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/71/477471/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # insert pdb breakpoint when pause_teardown is enabled if CONF.pause_teardown: cls.insert_pdb_breakpoint() def tearDown(self): super(BaseTestCase, self).tearDown() # insert pdb breakpoint when pause_teardown is enabled if CONF.pause_teardown: BaseTestCase.insert_pdb_breakpoint() @classmethod def insert_pdb_breakpoint(cls): """Add pdb breakpoint when pause_teardown is enabled. This could help in debugging process, Cleaning of resources is paused, so they ca be examined. """ import pdb pdb.set_trace()

commit_message:
Fix auto allocate network cleanup

AutoAllocateNetworkTest.resource_cleanup was trying to delete all
networks instead of only networks in its tenant. This leads to
failures if there happens to be another network (created by
something else) in a different tenant, since the context used is
non-admin and therefore lacks policy permission to delete things
in other tenants. The cleanup is herein changed to only cleanup
networks in the relevant tenant.

Change-Id: Ibc00ca976472cac46bf611f626d315d7e644f650
Closes-Bug: #1698382

subject: Add config settings for login domain dropdown
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-06-23 13:49:40.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/4b1530b51e92db0c50556cf15230fa75cc4d77a1', 'message': 'Add config settings for login domain dropdown

On clouds that use domain-specific Identity configuration[1], a user
must provide both their username and domain in order to log into
horizon. Without this patch, users must be aware of their domain's name
and enter it into a text box at login. This is sensible on public
clouds, because supplying potential domains to an unauthenticated user
exposes too much information about other customers and makes potential
attacks easier. On private clouds, however, it is a hinderance to
usability. For example, when migrating from a single-domain
configuration to a multi-domain configuration, users must now guess or
be informed of their domain in order to enter it in the text box. As
another example, when keystone domains are mapped to Active Directory
domains, the user may not be used to having to know their AD domains and
would prefer to select a likely one based on their geographical location
or department from a dropdown menu.

This patch adds the config file examples and documentation for new
config options, "OPENSTACK_KEYSTONE_DOMAIN_DROPDOWN" for enabling a
dropdown menu instead of a textbox when MULTIDOMAIN_SUPPORT is enabled,
and "OPENSTACK_KEYSTONE_DOMAIN_CHOICES" for providing domains to choose
from. The behavior changes corresponding to these new options are
implemented in django_openstack_auth in a corresponding patch.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/developer/keystone/configuration.html#domain-specific-drivers

Change-Id: I71d64182524d1f54745d9e42347b3a605fa2a920
Needed-By: Ie0a7e36b9975342fab81ddebb87880608d3ef187

commit_message:
Add config settings for login domain dropdown

On clouds that use domain-specific Identity configuration[1], a user
must provide both their username and domain in order to log into
horizon. Without this patch, users must be aware of their domain's name
and enter it into a text box at login. This is sensible on public
clouds, because supplying potential domains to an unauthenticated user
exposes too much information about other customers and makes potential
attacks easier. On private clouds, however, it is a hinderance to
usability. For example, when migrating from a single-domain
configuration to a multi-domain configuration, users must now guess or
be informed of their domain in order to enter it in the text box. As
another example, when keystone domains are mapped to Active Directory
domains, the user may not be used to having to know their AD domains and
would prefer to select a likely one based on their geographical location
or department from a dropdown menu.

This patch adds the config file examples and documentation for new
config options, "OPENSTACK_KEYSTONE_DOMAIN_DROPDOWN" for enabling a
dropdown menu instead of a textbox when MULTIDOMAIN_SUPPORT is enabled,
and "OPENSTACK_KEYSTONE_DOMAIN_CHOICES" for providing domains to choose
from. The behavior changes corresponding to these new options are
implemented in django_openstack_auth in a corresponding patch.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/developer/keystone/configuration.html#domain-specific-drivers

Change-Id: I71d64182524d1f54745d9e42347b3a605fa2a920
Depends-On: Ie0a7e36b9975342fab81ddebb87880608d3ef187
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/12/476912/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Set this to True if you want available domains displayed as a dropdown menu # on the login screen. It is strongly advised NOT to enable this for public # clouds, as advertising enabled domains to unauthenticated customers # irresponsibly exposes private information. This should only be used for # private clouds where the dashboard sits behind a corporate firewall. #OPENSTACK_KEYSTONE_DOMAIN_DROPDOWN=False # If OPENSTACK_KEYSTONE_DOMAIN_DROPDOWN is enabled, this option can be used to # set the available domains to choose from. This is a list of pairs whose first # value is the domain name and the second is the display name. #OPENSTACK_KEYSTONE_DOMAIN_CHOICES = ( # ('Default', 'Default'), #)

commit_message:
hardware offload support for openvswitch

In Kernel 4.8 we introduced Traffic Control (TC see [1]) hardware offloads
framework for SR-IOV VFs which allows us to configure the NIC [2].
Subsequent OVS patches [3] allow us to use the TC framework
to offload OVS datapath rules.

This patch adds plug/unplug when using ovs vif 'OVS_ACCELERATION'. The
plug method will lookup the VF representor and connect it to 'br-int',
while the unplug method will remove the VF representor from 'br-int'.

[1] https://linux.die.net/man/8/tc
[2] http://netdevconf.org/1.2/papers/efraim-gerlitz-sriov-ovs-final.pdf
[3] https://mail.openvswitch.org/pipermail/ovs-dev/2017-April/330606.html

Co-Authored-By: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

Change-Id: Ia8214d4da5edfdfc188dc4cf791613cb475dc4c3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/os-vif refs/changes/78/460278/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import errno import globimport reVIRTFN_RE = re.compile("virtfn(\d+)") set_interface_state(bridge, 'up')def set_interface_state(interface_name, port_state): processutils.execute('ip', 'link', 'set', interface_name, port_state, check_exit_code=[0, 2, 254]) @privsep.vif_plug.entrypoint def get_representor_port(pf_ifname, vf_num): """Get the representor netdevice which is corresponding to the VF. This method gets PF interface name and number of VF. It iterates over all the interfaces under the PF location and looks for interface that has the VF number in the phys_port_name. That interface is the representor for the requested VF. """ path = "/sys/class/net/%s/subsystem/" % pf_ifname try: for device in os.listdir(path): if device == pf_ifname: continue file_name = os.path.join(path, device, 'phys_port_name') if not os.path.isfile(file_name): continue try: representor_num = open("%s/%s/phys_port_name" % (path, device)).readline().rstrip() if int(representor_num) == int(vf_num): return device except IOError as e: # We want to ignore interfaces which we can't read their # phys_port_name file. with excutils.save_and_reraise_exception() as ctxt: if e.errno == errno.EOPNOTSUPP: ctxt.reraise = False except ValueError: # skip representor_num which we can't convert to integer continue except IOError: pass raise exception.RepresentorNotFound(ifname=pf_ifname, vf_num=vf_num) def _get_sysfs_netdev_path(pci_addr, pf_interface): """Get the sysfs path based on the PCI address of the device. Assumes a networking device - will not check for the existence of the path. """ if pf_interface: return "/sys/bus/pci/devices/%s/physfn/net" % (pci_addr) return "/sys/bus/pci/devices/%s/net" % (pci_addr) def get_ifname_by_pci_address(pci_addr, pf_interface=False): """Get the interface name based on a VF's pci address The returned interface name is either the parent PF's or that of the VF itself based on the argument of pf_interface. """ dev_path = _get_sysfs_netdev_path(pci_addr, pf_interface) try: dev_info = os.listdir(dev_path) return dev_info.pop() except Exception: raise exception.PciDeviceNotFoundById(id=pci_addr) def get_vf_num_by_pci_address(pci_addr): """Get the VF number based on a VF's pci address A VF is associated with an VF number, which ip link command uses to configure it. This number can be obtained from the PCI device filesystem. """ virtfns_path = "/sys/bus/pci/devices/%s/physfn/virtfn*" % (pci_addr) vf_num = None try: for vf_path in glob.iglob(virtfns_path): if re.search(pci_addr, os.readlink(vf_path)): t = VIRTFN_RE.search(vf_path) vf_num = t.group(1) break except Exception: pass if vf_num is None: raise exception.PciDeviceNotFoundById(id=pci_addr) return vf_num

subject: Remove pbr warnerrors in favor of sphinx check
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-05-09 07:40:04.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/mistral-specs/commit/bd52fb213c4394c34f6cf7ea29dc298082c01039', 'message': 'Remove pbr warnerrors in favor of sphinx check

This change removes the now unused "warnerrors" setting,
which is replaced by "warning-is-error" in sphinx
releases >= 1.5[0]. This also fixes any warnings
that came up when testing with the latest version
of sphinx:

- Redundant loading of todo extension
- Empty man_pages config value

Also updated the requirements for pbr and sphinx to the latest
version(s) in requirements.txt

With this change, any doc warnings will cause the build to fail
[0] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-March/113085.html

Change-Id: I2d111d3b305ca4dd0fa5c7e82112317135c75544

commit_message:
Remove pbr warnerrors in favor of sphinx check

This change removes the now unused "warnerrors" setting,
which is replaced by "warning-is-error" in sphinx
releases >= 1.5[0]. This also fixes any warnings
that came up when testing with the latest version
of sphinx:

- Redundant loading of todo extension
- Empty man_pages config value

Also updated the requirements for pbr and sphinx to the latest
version(s) in requirements.txt

With this change, any doc warnings will cause the build to fail
[0] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-March/113085.html

Change-Id: I2d111d3b305ca4dd0fa5c7e82112317135c75544
Co-Authored-By: bhavani <bhavani.r@nectechnologies.in>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/mistral-specs refs/changes/87/463487/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: builders = html warning-is-error = 1

commit_message:
[i18n] Don't convert exception.msg into string

Cinder exception.msg is already translatable, wrap
it with string format will make it untranslatable.

Change-Id: I705b818b292c00bee6c583029da091281485b790

commit_message:
[Urgent] Use neutron-lib.callbacks.resources

1. What is the problem
Resource attributes are moved from neutron.api.v2.attributes to
neutron-lib.callbacks.resources.

2. What is the solution for the problem
Use the resource definition in neutron-lib.callbacks.resources
module instead.

3. What features need to be implemented to the Tricircle to
realize the solution
N/A

Change-Id: I44dd334e6fea19286fee9821183af8b6458ecb48
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tricircle refs/changes/50/480350/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import neutron_lib.callbacks.resources as attributes

commit_message:
Don't set a default for docker_volume_size

When creating clusters, we should only pass the docker_volume_size
parameter to the magnum API if it was specified by the user. If not,
omitting it allows the API to set a default based on the cluster
template.

Change-Id: I510ff10d708a237be0cb88d3ff7094d7c81f5875
Closes-Bug: #1702314
Related-Bug: #1635244
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-magnumclient refs/changes/39/480239/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if docker_volume_size is not None: expected_args['docker_volume_size'] = docker_volume_size

commit_message:
Fix check_service_client_function doc typo

This commit fixes a doc typo of check_service_client_function to_utf
parameter in lib.tests.services.base.BaseServiceTest class. This
parameter is used for a response body not for a request body.

commit_message:
Bump API microversion to 1.7

The changes included in this version bump are:

- 'service-list' api
- 'node-adopt' api
- 'node-adopt-preview' api
- 'receiver-update' api

Change-Id: Ibc46f2cf6c47ff3e9f85c706a53fe079666402cd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/senlin refs/changes/05/479105/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 1.7 --- - Added ``node_adopt`` operation to node. - Added ``node_adopt_preview`` operation to node. - Added ``receiver_update`` operation to receiver. - Added ``service_list`` API.

Fix openstackdocstheme settings

To use openstackdocstheme 1.11.0 properly, this patch fixes
some settings according to follow.
https://docs.openstack.org/openstackdocstheme/latest/

commit_message:
Modify the execution of alter_enum_add_value SQL

'%' (value) s in the execution SQL statement of alter_enum_add_value
should be decorated with ' '

Ralated commit I4767222ba97d9c35c011adfc187b2977975f981a

Change-Id: I24138e5b4ec8b3c3126ae5ff79e26ecb91a65d69

commit_message:
Update README with installation instructions

Change-Id: If888f677d235c8dc509c6037d6462ebacbd68b77
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/congress-dashboard refs/changes/90/478390/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Congress Dashboard is an extension for OpenStack Dashboard that provides a UI for Congress. With congress-dashboard, a user is able to easily write the policies and rules for governance of cloud. The following below instructions assumes that Horizon is already installed and its installation folder is <horizon>. Detailed information on how to install Horizon can be found at http://docs.openstack.org/developer/horizon/quickstart.html#setup. The installation folder of Congress Dashboard will be referred to as <congress-dashboard>. Clone Congress-Dashboard .. code-block:: console $ git clone https://github.com/openstack/congress-dashboard.git $ cd congress-dashboard Install requirements .. code-block:: console $ sudo pip install . Install Source code .. code-block:: console $ sudo python setup.py install ln -s <congress-dashboard>/congress_dashboard/enabled/_50_policy.py <horizon>/openstack_dashboard/local/enabled ln -s <congress-dashboard>/congress_dashboard/enabled/_60_policies.py <horizon>/openstack_dashboard/local/enabled ln -s <congress-dashboard>/congress_dashboard/enabled/_70_datasources.py <horizon>/openstack_dashboard/local/enabled Restart Apache server .. code-block:: console $ sudo service apache2 restart
deleted_lines: Features -------- * TODO Begin by cloning the Horizon and Congress Dashboard repositories:: git clone https://github.com/openstack/horizon git clone https://github.com/openstack/congress-dashboard Create a virtual environment and install Horizon dependencies:: cd horizon python tools/install_venv.py Set up your ``local_settings.py`` file:: cp openstack_dashboard/local/local_settings.py.example openstack_dashboard/local/local_settings.py Open up the copied ``local_settings.py`` file in your preferred text editor. You will want to customize several settings: - ``OPENSTACK_HOST`` should be configured with the hostname of your OpenStack server. Verify that the ``OPENSTACK_KEYSTONE_URL`` and ``OPENSTACK_KEYSTONE_DEFAULT_ROLE`` settings are correct for your environment. (They should be correct unless you modified your OpenStack server to change them.) Install Congress Dashboard with all dependencies in your virtual environment:: tools/with_venv.sh pip install -e ../congress-dashboard/ ln -s ../congress-dashboard/congress_dashboard/enabled/_50_policy.py openstack_dashboard/local/enabled ln -s ../congress-dashboard/congress_dashboard/enabled/_60_policies.py openstack_dashboard/local/enabled ln -s ../congress-dashboard/congress_dashboard/enabled/_70_datasources.py openstack_dashboard/local/enabled To run horizon with the newly enabled Congress Dashboard plugin run:: ./run_tests.sh --runserver 0.0.0.0:8080 to have the application start on port 8080 and the horizon dashboard will be ayvailable in your browser at http://localhost:8080/

commit_message:
Add dsl_iterators_limit config option

To remove hardcoded constant called 'ITERATORS_LIMIT', that can be
exceeded (2000) having big amount of objects. It is easy to achieve
in big cloud with user that is allowed to view lots of resources.

Change-Id: I6b4fd9d2904c59daa525020f271506c536ae614b
Closes-Bug: #1690179
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/murano refs/changes/49/480349/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- fixes: - | Remove hardcoded constant called 'ITERATORS_LIMIT', that can be exceeded (2000) having big amount of objects. Introduce dsl_iterators_limit configuration option.

commit_message:
Fix api-ref for v3 volume and snapshot manage

From cinder api v3.8, manageable_volumes and manageable_snapshot
rest sources were added that were previously in api extensions.
This patch is to replace os-manage-[volume|snapshot] with
manageable_[volumes|snapshots] in v3 api-ref.

Change-Id: I7b9af1a1243adb082581bc3c67d8697eacc3e70a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/24/471624/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Volume manage extension (manageable_volumes).. rest_method:: POST /v3/{project_id}/manageable_volumesthe existing storage volume to the next gigabyte (GiB)... rest_method:: GET /v3/{project_id}/manageable_volumes.. rest_method:: GET /v3/{project_id}/manageable_volumes/detail
deleted_lines: Volume manage extension (os-volume-manage).. rest_method:: POST /v3/{project_id}/os-volume-managethe existing storage volume to the next gibibyte (GiB)... rest_method:: GET /v3/{project_id}/os-volume-manage.. rest_method:: GET /v3/{project_id}/os-volume-manage/detail

commit_message:
Add REST API for volume connector and volume target operation

This patch introduces following REST API endpoints to get/set volume
connector and volume target in Ironic.

- GET /v1/volume
- GET /v1/nodes/<node_uuid or name>/volume
- {GET, POST} /v1/volume/connectors
- {GET, PATCH, DELETE} /v1/volume/connectors/<volume_connector_uuid>
- GET /v1/nodes/<node_uuid or name>/volume/connectors
- {GET, POST} /v1/volume/targets
- {GET, PATCH, DELETE} /v1/volume/targets/<volume_target_uuid>
- GET /v1/nodes/<node_uuid or name>/volume/targets

This also adds CRUD notifications for volume connector and volume
target.

Co-Authored-By: Tomoki Sekiyama <tomoki.sekiyama.qu@hitachi.com>
Co-Authored-By: David Lenwell <dlenwell@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Hironori Shiina <shiina.hironori@jp.fujitsu.com>
Change-Id: I328a698f2109841e1e122e17fea4b345c4179161
Partial-Bug: 1526231
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/86/214586/98 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from ironic.api.controllers.v1 import volume_connector volume_connectors = wsme.wsattr([link.Link], readonly=True) """Links to the collection of volume connectors on this node""" node.volume_connectors = \ [link.Link.make_link('self', url, 'nodes', node_uuid + "/volume_connectors"), link.Link.make_link('bookmark', url, 'nodes', node_uuid + "/volume_connectors", bookmark=True) ] volume_connectors = volume_connector.VolumeConnectorsController() """Expose volume connectors as a sub-element of nodes""" volume_connectors.from_nodes = True

subject: Fix openstackdocstheme settings
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-06-30 06:50:21.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/deb-cinder/commit/2a744255626094cd427cbd48024ac8852692c7a2', 'message': 'Fix openstackdocstheme settings

To use openstackdocstheme 1.11.0 properly, this patch fixe
some settings according to follow.

commit_message:
Switch from oslosphinx to openstackdocstheme

To use openstackdocstheme 1.11.0 properly, this patch fixes
some settings according to follow.
https://docs.openstack.org/openstackdocstheme/latest/

Change-Id: I07652e3a086a650ab9f08f6da7ddf0e8145b2969

subject: Move base_client from volume.v3 to volume
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-06-19 06:26:26.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/0c6eac0555d8b546b3ff42de281c86511b2e182a', 'message': 'Move base_client from volume.v3 to volume

In order to avoid the multiple inheritance when adding new interfaces in
volume v3 clients, e.g., if we want to add update_backup in volume v3
BackupsClient, we have to make volume.v3.BackupsClient inherit from both
volume.v3.base_client.BaseClient and volume.v2.backups_client.BackupsClient
(see https://review.openstack.org/#/c/461263), and this situation will
repeat everytime we add new interfaces in volume v3 clients based on v2
clients.
This is to move volume.v3.base_client to volume, and if we want to add new
interfaces based on a v2 client, we can make that v2 client inherit from
volume.base_client.BaseClient to get microversion support, and then to make
the new v3 client inherit from the v2 client, thus to avoid the multiple
inheritance.

Change-Id: I645ae35daebd924c4c4523163e5419cc050bb0ed
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2017-06-20 02:33:26.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/c719d09781b0bb818ab248acce4932d0e53f866f', 'message': 'Move base_client from volume.v3 to volume

Now exists multiple inheritance when adding new interfaces in
volume v3 clients, e.g., if we want to add show_volume_summary
in volume v3 VolumesClient, we have to make volume.v3.VolumesClient
inherit from both volume.v3.base_client.BaseClient and volume.v2.
volumes_client.VolumesClient, and this situation will repeat
everytime we add new interfaces in volume v3 clients based on v2
clients.
This is to move volume.v3.base_client to volume, and if we want to
add new interfaces based on a v2 client, we can make that v2 client
inherit from volume.base_client.BaseClient to get microversion support,
and then to make the new v3 client inherit from the v2 client, thus
to avoid the multiple inheritance.

Change-Id: I645ae35daebd924c4c4523163e5419cc050bb0ed

commit_message:
Move base_client from volume.v3 to volume

Now exists multiple inheritance when adding new interfaces in
volume v3 clients, e.g., if we want to add show_volume_summary
in volume v3 VolumesClient, we have to make volume.v3.VolumesClient
inherit from both volume.v3.base_client.BaseClient and volume.v2.
volumes_client.VolumesClient, and this situation will repeat
everytime we add new interfaces in volume v3 clients based on v2
clients.
This is to move volume.v3.base_client to volume, and if we want to
add new interfaces based on a v2 client, we can make that v2 client
inherit from volume.base_client.BaseClient to get microversion support,
and then to make the new v3 client inherit from the v2 client, thus
to avoid the multiple inheritance.

Change-Id: I645ae35daebd924c4c4523163e5419cc050bb0ed

commit_message:
Using assertFalse(A) instead of assertEqual(False, A)

This patch is to replace assertEqual(False, A) with assertFalse(A), which
the latter is more straightforward and easier to understand.
Similar to a merged patch https://review.openstack.org/#/c/473749/

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-06-14 06:39:13.000000000', 'files': ['tackerclient/tacker/v1_0/__init__.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-tackerclient/commit/b7a494e7d4318877a0a98811841a282212b40607', 'message': 'Replace six.iteritems() with .items()

will more readable. 2.In py2, the performance
about list should be negligible, see the link [2].
[1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Python3
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-June/066391.html

Change-Id: I988ff08fe1d6bc52c4a601641c564db7881accf4
'}]
commit_message:
Replace six.iteritems() with .items()

1.As mentioned in [1], we should avoid usingg
six.iteritems to achieve iterators. We can
use dict.items instead, as it will return
iterators in PY3 as well. And dict.items/keys
will more readable. 2.In py2, the performance
about list should be negligible, see the link [2].
[1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Python3
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-June/066391.html

Change-Id: I988ff08fe1d6bc52c4a601641c564db7881accf4

commit_message:
Remove dothill driver

The Dot Hill driver is no longer supported by an independent CI, so
the driver was marked unsupported in the Ocata release, and is being
disabled in Pike.  The driver code remains in place since it's
subclassed by other drivers (lenovo, hpmsa), but attempting to load
the dothill driver will throw an exception.

DocImpact: Remove description of Dot Hill AssuredSAN driver

UpgradeImpact: Dot Hill storage requires configuration of a new driver.

Change-Id: Ic2cec24ac33813cbce4c3166cc04f32ad3df6396

commit_message:
update the description of the file path - "meters.yaml"

The file has been moved from ceilometer/meter/data/meters.yaml to
ceilometer/data/meters.d/meters.yaml, in order to support loading
multiple meter definition files. Refer to bug: #1479775.

The description in openstack-maunals also need to be updated. There
is only one which in "telemetry-data-collection.rst" involved.

This patch remove the wrong path and add the content about using
multiple meter definition files.

Change-Id: I36ec5e2c78ca5c030d77b7ba621c1f0c78515c52

subject: Expand tag length limit to 80
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-01-17 00:54:31.000000000', 'files': ['nova/objects/tag.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/2d37528a44ceab6018c07fecb1aea967fdd455ff', 'message': 'Expand tag length limit to 80

The tag has a limited length, and in the current
implementation, it is 60 in the tag object definition:
http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/nova/tree/nova/objects/tag.py#n18

but 80 in the db model:
http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/nova/tree/nova/db/sqlalchemy/models.py#n1464

We should expand the limitation in tag object definition
to 80 as we have already created a 80 long space in db and
this may be confusing. Besides, users can enjoy longer tags.

Change-Id: Ie551ae57c7e056c50ef5b4fbba2480cc46df3370
Closes-Bug: #1656978
'}]
commit_message:
Expand tag length limit to 80

The tag has a limited length, and in the current
implementation, it is 60 in the tag object definition:
http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/nova/tree/nova/objects/tag.py#n18

but 80 in the db model:
http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/nova/tree/nova/db/sqlalchemy/models.py#n1464

We should expand the limitation in tag object definition
to 80 as we have already created a 80 long space in db and
this may be confusing. Besides, users can enjoy longer tags.

Change-Id: Ie551ae57c7e056c50ef5b4fbba2480cc46df3370
Closes-Bug: #1656978
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/04/421004/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: MAX_TAG_LENGTH = 80

commit_message:
Check destination_type when booting with bdm provided

When booting instance with block_device_mapping provided,
in the current implementation, the "destination_type" is
allowed to be None, and this lead to a silent failed bug.

The BDM record created at nova api layer and saved in DB.
Then in the nova-compute, the BDM record with
destination_type=None will be ignored by the nova code.

This patch adds a check for destination_type

Change-Id: Ie18c469fb4974cc1e79172acdc64596939dc144c
partial-bug: #1644725
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/72/402372/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if destination_type not in ('volume', 'local'): raise exception.InvalidBDMFormat( details=_("Invalid destination_type field."))

commit_message:
api-ref: verification for os-server-actions(1)

This series of patchs aim to complete the verification
for os-server-actions, since os-server-actions.inc
contain over 40 APIs, they will be verified about
3-5 APIs per patch.

This is the first patch of the series, fix including
- main discription
- floating IP actions
- security group actions
- admin password actions

Part of blueprint api-ref-in-rst-ocata

Change-Id: Iec5bdbd6c49403b160d37da4fb816727a2e65ceb

You can also trigger a crash dump.. note:: The following server actions are considered as calling proxy APIs, and are deprecated in Microversion 2.34, users should use the APIs provided by related services: - associate/disassociate a fixed or floating IP address with a server - attach/detach a volume to a server - add a security group to or remove a security group from a server - updating security group rules
deleted_lines: also change the password of the server and add a security group to or remove a security group from a server. You can also trigger a crash dump

commit_message:
Transform instance.resize_prep notification

The instance.resize_prep.start and instance.resize_prep.end
notifications are transformed to the versioned framework.

Change-Id: Icf657ec70927b8d876f5f0a8a6550a898e9d2704
Implements: bp versioned-notification-transformation-ocata

commit_message:
Cleanup api validation tests(1).

As mentioned in cyeoh's comment in api/validation/__init__.py
the unittests should be rewrite to not put req in kwargs.

This patch clean up test_api_validation.py

Change-Id: I80a37abe6f1e88f880709445f1a2098390e95039
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/64/417664/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ver = args[1].api_version_request legacy_v2 = args[1].is_legacy_v2()
deleted_lines: # The request object is always the second argument. # However numerous unittests pass in the request object # via kwargs instead so we handle that as well. # TODO(cyeoh): cleanup unittests so we don't have to # to do this if 'req' in kwargs: ver = kwargs['req'].api_version_request legacy_v2 = kwargs['req'].is_legacy_v2() else: ver = args[1].api_version_request legacy_v2 = args[1].is_legacy_v2()

subject: Verify config support cinder on subpath
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-06-12 15:55:36.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/1c34a0286a25fafd0d20f870b8bea09f0025d1aa', 'message': 'WIP. Dirty hack to test cinder-api with uWSGI

Change-Id: Ie8a0eeab1bf31887d6f37cf155b2d161ddfb172d
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2017-06-13 10:34:49.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/a06461e33bd92d961e51af163f70022e244b69e7', 'message': " Verify config support cindere on subpath

verify-config should support cibdere running on a subpath.
Currently it doesn't because it strips the entire path from the
identity endpoint in the catalog when calculating the
unversioned endpoint. The fix is to only strip off the last part of
the path.

Change-Id: Ie8a0eeab1bf31887d6f37cf155b2d161ddfb172d
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2017-06-13 10:39:06.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/b36288313bc3fc2e365a48938293e0afb714890a', 'message': "Verify config support cindere on subpath

verify-config should support cibdere running on a subpath.
Currently it doesn't because it strips the entire path from the
identity endpoint in the catalog when calculating the
unversioned endpoint. The fix is to only strip off the last part of
the path.

Change-Id: Ie8a0eeab1bf31887d6f37cf155b2d161ddfb172d
"}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2017-06-13 10:51:47.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/97e109e01d81eace27f1f17a343df531270e1dfd', 'message': "Verify config support cindere on subpath

verify-config should support cibdere running on a subpath.
Currently it doesn't because it strips the entire path from the
identity endpoint in the catalog when calculating the
unversioned endpoint. The fix is to only strip off the last part of

commit_message:
Verify config support cinder on subpath

verify-config should support cinder running on a subpath.
Currently it doesn't because it strips the entire path from the
identity endpoint in the catalog when calculating the
unversioned endpoint. The fix is to only strip off the last part of
the path.

Change-Id: Ie8a0eeab1bf31887d6f37cf155b2d161ddfb172d

commit_message:
Add custom keyring when initializing RBD connection

Added RBD keyring configuration parameter which will help administrator
set an custom keyring path to the Ceph cluster.

Closes-bug: #1668304

Change-Id: I263cc10dc877b20bbc205ea55173ad3878687ea1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/72/456672/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _generate_keyring_path(self): path = None rbd_user = self.configuration.rbd_user cluster_name = self.configuration.rbd_cluster_name ceph_conf = self.configuration.rbd_ceph_conf replace_words = { "%s." % cluster_name: "%s.client.%s." % (cluster_name, rbd_user), '.conf': '.keyring' } if ceph_conf != '/etc/ceph/ceph.conf': path = ceph_conf for k, v in replace_words.iteritems(): path = path.replace(k, v) return path keyring_path = self._generate_keyring_path() 'keyring': keyring_path,

commit_message:
Fix import error "No module named six.moves" for plugin sanity job

This commit fixes the import error "No module named six.moves" without
using the module for the plugin sanity job. Because the job call the
script directly.

Change-Id: Id0fa1b15fe443d65a1b6ca008e490d0fa54d6b32

commit_message:
Revert "Remove startup check from devstack"

This reverts commit 4a1a6b3766b7cd63afff36307a8044cf3b848a31. It didn't
improve the situation, and at least it's failing early.

Conflicts:
	devstack/plugin.sh

Change-Id: Idf16037e6a3bbc7f915e12827348eda663721d5e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/zaqar refs/changes/47/479847/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: echo "Waiting for Zaqar to start..." token=$(openstack token issue -c id -f value) if ! timeout $SERVICE_TIMEOUT sh -c "while ! wget --no-proxy -q --header=\"Client-ID:$(uuidgen)\" --header=\"X-Auth-Token:$token\" -O- $ZAQAR_SERVICE_PROTOCOL://$ZAQAR_SERVICE_HOST:$ZAQAR_SERVICE_PORT/v2/ping; do sleep 1; done"; then die $LINENO "Zaqar did not start" fi

commit_message:
switch from oslosphinx to openstackdocstheme

Change-Id: I2f1f8f76b6ec732a770707a259dc72a2f576e46c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/71/479871/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: try: import openstackdocstheme extensions.append('openstackdocstheme') except ImportError: openstackdocstheme = None repository_name = 'openstack/ironic' bug_project = 'ironic' bug_tag = '' html_last_updated_fmt = '%Y-%m-%d %H:%M' if openstackdocstheme is not None: html_theme = 'openstackdocs' else: html_theme = 'default'

subject: Don't delete neutron port when attach failed
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-11-28 09:03:40.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/15710270bd0ffee95c984db87f865935f90eff06', 'message': "Don't delete neutron port when attach failed

Currently, when attaching netron pre-existing
port to an instance, if the attach failed, it
will also be deleted in Neutron side due to
bad judgement of the who created the port by
reading instance.info_cache(the record may
not be updated yet). The same problem would
appear when detach a neutron port quickly
before the info_cache got updated.

This patch fixed it by simply using data
from virtual_interface table to judge the
creater of the port.

Change-Id: Ib323b74d4ea1e874b476ab5addfc6bc79cb7c751
closes-bug: #1645175

"}, {'number': 32, 'created': '2017-06-21 03:38:35.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/862aa537386dbf9e97c04092b5d533982cd21981', 'message': "Don't delete neutron port when attach failed

Currently, when attaching neutron pre-existing
port to an instance, if the attach failed, it
will also be deleted in Neutron side due to
bad judgement of the who created the port by
reading not up-to-date info_cache.

The workflow starts at:
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/9ed0d611453aee7a27debd773bdbe146510be0ad/nova/network/neutronv2/api.py#L881
ordered_ports and preexisting_port_ids are
the same when attaching a preexisting port
to an instance and it calls
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/9ed0d611453aee7a27debd773bdbe146510be0ad/nova/network/base_api.py#L246
which calls back into the neutronv2 api code
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/9ed0d611453aee7a27debd773bdbe146510be0ad/nova/network/neutronv2/api.py#L1274
and at this point, compute_utils.refresh_info_cache_for_instance(context,
instance) won't have the newly attached port in it(see
debug log: http://paste.openstack.org/show/613232/)
because _build_network_info_model() is going to
process it. The instance obj in memoryt with old
info_cache will be used at rollback process and
causing the miss-judging.

This patch fixed it by updating instance.info_cache
to the new ic after it is created.

Co-Authored-By: huangtianhua@huawei.com
Change-Id: Ib323b74d4ea1e874b476ab5addfc6bc79cb7c751
closes-bug: #1645175
"}, {'number': 33, 'created': '2017-06-21 06:32:14.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/e61f1cc41e7bedb77b2c22873b43199f6381b611', 'message': "Don't delete neutron port when attach failed

closes-bug: #1645175

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/9ed0d6114/nova/network/neutronv2/api.py#L881
ordered_ports and preexisting_port_ids are
the same when attaching a preexisting port
to an instance and it calls
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/9ed0d6114/nova/network/base_api.py#L246
which calls back into the neutronv2 api code
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/9ed0d6114/nova/network/neutronv2/api.py#L1274
and at this point, compute_utils.refresh_info_cache_for_instance(context,
instance) won't have the newly attached port in it(see
debug log: http://paste.openstack.org/show/613232/)
because _build_network_info_model() is going to
process it. The instance obj in memoryt with old
info_cache will be used at rollback process and
causing the miss-judging.

This patch fixed it by updating instance.info_cache
to the new ic after it is created.

Co-Authored-By: huangtianhua@huawei.com
Change-Id: Ib323b74d4ea1e874b476ab5addfc6bc79cb7c751

commit_message:
Don't delete neutron port when attach failed

Currently, when attaching neutron pre-existing
port to an instance, if the attach failed, it
will also be deleted in Neutron side due to
bad judgement of the who created the port by
reading not up-to-date info_cache.

The workflow starts at:
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/9ed0d6114/nova/network/neutronv2/api.py#L881
ordered_ports and preexisting_port_ids are
the same when attaching a preexisting port
to an instance and it calls
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/9ed0d6114/nova/network/base_api.py#L246
which calls back into the neutronv2 api code
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/9ed0d6114/nova/network/neutronv2/api.py#L1274
and at this point, compute_utils.refresh_info_cache_for_instance(context,
instance) won't have the newly attached port in it(see
debug log: http://paste.openstack.org/show/613232/)
because _build_network_info_model() is going to
process it. The instance obj in memoryt with old
info_cache will be used at rollback process and
causing the miss-judging.

This patch fixed it by updating instance.info_cache
to the new ic after it is created.

Co-Authored-By: huangtianhua@huawei.com
Change-Id: Ib323b74d4ea1e874b476ab5addfc6bc79cb7c751
closes-bug: #1645175
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/68/403568/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self._delete_ports(neutron, instance, [port_id], raise_if_fail=True) self._unbind_ports(context, [port_id], neutron)
deleted_lines: preexisting_ports = self._get_preexisting_port_ids(instance) if port_id in preexisting_ports: self._unbind_ports(context, [port_id], neutron) else: self._delete_ports(neutron, instance, [port_id], raise_if_fail=True)

commit_message:
don't make ssh_config files executable

we were setting mode 0755 on generated ssh configuration files. this
patch changes that to 0644.

Change-Id: I621e0ef9b5ba8a282c8a043e16c2b5c047513ac6

commit_message:
Neutron: nova_metadata_ip property is deprecated

As described here:
https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/conf/agent/metadata/config.py#L47
nova_metadata_host must be used.

Change-Id: Idd1c2a8beebf39a3c420cbf1f1268f9935d938bb

deleted_lines: nova_metadata_ip = {% if orchestration_engine == 'KUBERNETES' %}nova-metadata{% else %}{{ kolla_internal_fqdn }}{% endif %}

commit_message:
Add test cases for oauth1 token related APIs.

Add test_oauth_tokens_rbac.py with RBAC test cases
related to OAUTH1 token APIs

Change-Id: I811ae810f95266f950a867d2993d56f632d20495
Co-Authored-By: Nishant Kumar <nk613n@att.com>
Co-Authored-By: Hemanth Nakkina <nh863p@att.com>
Depends-On: I4c5369ae3ad7a7add630e3ac6a4fc52f854bc77c
Closes-Bug: #1686076

added_lines: from oauthlib import oauth1 from six.moves import urllib from tempest import config CONF = config.CONF def _create_consumer_request_token(self): # Create a consumer consumer = self._create_consumer() consumer_id = consumer['id'] consumer_secret = consumer['secret'] consumer = {'key': consumer_id, 'secret': consumer_secret} project_id = self.auth_provider.credentials.project_id body = self.oauth_token_client.create_request_token( consumer_id, consumer_secret, project_id) request_key = body['oauth_token'] request_secret = body['oauth_token_secret'] request_token = {'key': request_key, 'secret': request_secret} roles = self.roles_client.list_roles() for role in roles['roles']: if role['name'] == CONF.rbac.rbac_test_role: role_id = role['id'] break; return (request_token, role_id, consumer) def _create_access_token(self): request_token, role_id, consumer = \ self._create_consumer_request_token() roles = [] roles.append(role_id) # Authorize request token resp = self.oauth_token_client.authorize_request_token( request_token['key'], roles)['token'] auth_verifier = resp['oauth_verifier'] request_token.update({'verifier': auth_verifier}) # Create Access Token body = self.oauth_token_client.create_access_token( consumer['key'], consumer['secret'], request_token['key'], request_token['secret'], auth_verifier) access_key = body['oauth_token'] return access_key @rbac_rule_validation.action(service="keystone", rule="identity:create_request_token") @decorators.idempotent_id('0f148510-63bf-11e6-4522-080044d0d976') def test_create_request_token(self): consumer = self._create_consumer() consumer_id = consumer['id'] consumer_secret = consumer['secret'] project_id = self.auth_provider.credentials.project_id self.rbac_utils.switch_role(self, toggle_rbac_role=True) self.oauth_token_client.create_request_token( consumer_id, consumer_secret, project_id) @rbac_rule_validation.action(service="keystone", rule="identity:create_access_token") @decorators.idempotent_id('0f148510-63bf-11e6-4522-080044d0d977') def test_create_access_token(self): """ Create access token """ request_token, role_id, consumer = \ self._create_consumer_request_token() roles = [] roles.append(role_id) # Authorize request token resp = self.oauth_token_client.authorize_request_token( request_token['key'], roles)['token'] outh_verifier = resp['oauth_verifier'] request_token.update({'verifier': outh_verifier}) self.rbac_utils.switch_role(self, toggle_rbac_role=True) self.oauth_token_client.create_access_token(consumer['key'], consumer['secret'], request_token['key'], request_token['secret'], outh_verifier) @rbac_rule_validation.action(service="keystone", rule="identity:authorize_request_token") @decorators.idempotent_id('0f148510-63bf-11e6-4522-080044d0d978') def test_authorize_request_token(self): """ Authorize request token """ request_token, role_id, _ = self._create_consumer_request_token() roles = [] roles.append(role_id) self.rbac_utils.switch_role(self, toggle_rbac_role=True) self.oauth_token_client.authorize_request_token( request_token['key'], roles) @rbac_rule_validation.action(service="keystone", rule="identity:get_access_token") @decorators.idempotent_id('0f148510-63bf-11e6-4522-080044d0d979') def test_get_access_token(self): """ Get access token """ access_token = self._create_access_token() user_id = self.auth_provider.credentials.user_id self.rbac_utils.switch_role(self, toggle_rbac_role=True) self.oauth_token_client.get_access_token(user_id, access_token) @rbac_rule_validation.action(service="keystone", rule="identity:list_access_token_roles") @decorators.idempotent_id('0f148510-63bf-11e6-4522-080044d0d980') def test_list_access_token_roles(self): """ List access token roles """ access_token = self._create_access_token() user_id = self.auth_provider.credentials.user_id self.rbac_utils.switch_role(self, toggle_rbac_role=True) self.oauth_token_client.list_access_token_roles( user_id, access_token) @rbac_rule_validation.action(service="keystone", rule="identity:list_access_tokens") @decorators.idempotent_id('0f148510-63bf-11e6-4522-080044d0d981') def test_list_access_tokens(self): """ List access tokens """ access_token = self._create_access_token() user_id = self.auth_provider.credentials.user_id self.rbac_utils.switch_role(self, toggle_rbac_role=True) self.oauth_token_client.list_access_tokens(user_id) @rbac_rule_validation.action(service="keystone", rule="identity:get_access_token_role") @decorators.idempotent_id('0f148510-63bf-11e6-4522-080044d0d982') def test_get_access_token_role(self): """ Get role details for an access token """ access_token = self._create_access_token() user_id = self.auth_provider.credentials.user_id roles = self.roles_client.list_roles() for role in roles['roles']: if role['name'] == CONF.rbac.rbac_test_role: role_id = role['id'] break; self.rbac_utils.switch_role(self, toggle_rbac_role=True) self.oauth_token_client.get_access_token_role( user_id, access_token, role_id) @rbac_rule_validation.action(service="keystone", rule="identity:revoke_access_token") @decorators.idempotent_id('0f148510-63bf-11e6-4522-080044d0d983') def test_delete_access_token(self): """ Revoke access token """ user_id = self.auth_provider.credentials.user_id access_token = self._create_access_token() self.rbac_utils.switch_role(self, toggle_rbac_role=True) self.oauth_token_client.delete_access_token( user_id, access_token)

commit_message:
Convert role templates to consume roles_data map

Currently we only consume the name with a special-case
for the disable constraints boolean, but it will be more
flexible if we consume the whole roles_data mapping for
each role, so that e.g composable networks and other
per-role customizations can be expressed in these
templates

Partially-Implements: blueprint composable-networks
Depends-On: Id1249b78b3dd87e91d572ffa31b7a541f3cde2c7
Change-Id: I355534ec456479944f66106e957404a660d8f2d2

commit_message:
New environment file to configure containers.

This is part of a larger series that changes the interface used
for configuring which containers are used.  This needs CI and
possibly quickstart updates to use this environment file so CI
will continue to pass.

Change-Id: I125137ba45f608cf84ea0a7146edd744a549d23b
Co-Authored-By: Dan Prince <dprince@redhat.com>

commit_message:
use core resource attribute constants from neutron-lib

neutron-lib now contains the API definitions for neutron's core
resources. This patch removes the constant core resource and collection
variables and uses them from lib. Subsequent patches will consume the
actual core resource attribute definitions.

NeutronLibImpact

Change-Id: Ia9afdf620cd538b2aa420593277d6403a45c996b

subject: Fix bootstrap-servers with invalid api_interface
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-02-16 14:33:10.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible/commit/57582f59bd995df14de494e32639a1d98acac88e', 'message': "Fix bootstrap-servers with invalid api_interface

When bootstrapping a host for kolla-ansible the 'kolla-ansible
bootstrap-servers' command can fail if for any of the hosts the
'api_interface' is invalid. This could be true for a number of reasons:

- The 'api_interface' variable is undefined.
- The host does not have a network interface matching 'api_interface'.

Valid causes for the second point include:
- The Ansible control host (localhost) is in the inventory but is not
  intended to be a target host.
- One of the hosts (currently must be localhost) is a Bifrost host,
  which does not need a valid api_interface.
- The services mapped to the host do not require the use of an
  api_interface.

This change checks for a valid api_interface variable for the host and
its presence in the host's hostvars before accessing the variable.
This results in successful completion of the command, with the omission
of host entries for those hosts without a valid api_interface.

Change-Id: Ie111ef54130adf2556ce83c402cdbb5058ace4f6
Closes-bug: #1665364
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2017-03-02 16:41:54.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible/commit/c34242b3df14dcf6c8adf35c29ffff3e48a44cfe', 'message': "Fix bootstrap-servers with invalid api_interface

When bootstrapping a host for kolla-ansible the 'kolla-ansible
bootstrap-servers' command can fail if for any of the hosts the
'api_interface' is invalid. This could be true for a number of reasons:

- The 'api_interface' variable is undefined.
- The host does not have a network interface matching 'api_interface'.

Valid causes for the second point include:
- The Ansible control host (localhost) is in the inventory but is not
  intended to be a target host.
- One of the hosts (currently must be localhost) is a Bifrost host,
  which does not need a valid api_interface.
- The services mapped to the host do not require the use of an
  api_interface.

This change checks for a valid api_interface variable for the host and
its presence in the host's hostvars before accessing the variable.
This results in successful completion of the command, with the omission
of host entries for those hosts without a valid api_interface.

Change-Id: Ie111ef54130adf2556ce83c402cdbb5058ace4f6
Closes-bug: #1665364
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2017-06-12 13:25:31.000000000', 'files': ['ansible/roles/baremetal/tasks/pre-install.yml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible/commit/64b09d6eb0734249843bfc4f8fc8058222bf3804', 'message': "Fix bootstrap-servers with invalid api_interface

When bootstrapping a host for kolla-ansible the 'kolla-ansible
bootstrap-servers' command can fail if for any of the hosts the
'api_interface' is invalid. This happen if the host does not have a
network interface matching 'api_interface'. This is possible on
a host running bifrost, as bifrost does not require the api_interface
variable to be set.

This change avoids adding a hosts entry for hosts in the bifrost group
that do not have a valid api_interface. It also avoids modifying the
hosts file on hosts in the bifrost group that do not have a valid
api_interface.

Change-Id: Ie111ef54130adf2556ce83c402cdbb5058ace4f6
Closes-bug: #1665364
"}]
commit_message:
Fix bootstrap-servers with invalid api_interface

When bootstrapping a host for kolla-ansible the 'kolla-ansible
bootstrap-servers' command can fail if for any of the hosts the
'api_interface' is invalid. This happen if the host does not have a
network interface matching 'api_interface'. This is possible on
a host running bifrost, as bifrost does not require the api_interface
variable to be set.

This change avoids adding a hosts entry for hosts in the bifrost group
that do not have a valid api_interface. It also avoids modifying the
hosts file on hosts in the bifrost group that do not have a valid
api_interface.

Change-Id: Ie111ef54130adf2556ce83c402cdbb5058ace4f6
Closes-bug: #1665364

commit_message:
Optimize helpinfo in zun/conf

Remove function _() from zun/conf. Currently, some configs helpinfo
has translation and the others do not, which is inconsistent.
There are two options to resolve this. The first option is to remove
all translation from config. The second option is to enforce
translation for all configs. This commit suggested the first option
because configs are not directly exposed to end-users so the value
of translated configs helpinfo is not too much.

Change-Id: Iadd8333b5156696477b4dced01077e77fa42afb2

Add support for metric_cleanup_delay option

metric_cleanup_delay option is useful to configure the number of seconds
to wait between cleaning of expired data.

commit_message:
introduces a linuxbridge os-vif experimental job.

- This change introduces a new job for testing the
  linuxbridge os-vif plugin.
- This change enables
  gate-tempest-dsvm-nova-os-vif-linuxbridge-ubuntu-xenial-nv
  for both the nova and os-vif experimental pipelines.
- Once this job is shown to be stable it will be moved to
  the check/gate pipelines for os-vif to ensure future changes
  to os-vif do not break compatibility with nova and neutron for
  the linuxbridge backend.

Change-Id: I41238832248eb87e46c94391abf15adcb2862b0d

commit_message:
Introduce rolling updates for daemonsets

Kubernetes 1.6 introduced the ability to declare an update
strategy for daemonsets. As weve made >1.6 a requirement, we
should adopt the ability to update our daemonsets just as we do
with deployments. This brings the daemonset templates in our
charts in line with other patterns developed.

Change-Id: I317560b24d65274b69bec2df4f6225f1255b7ae6

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-07-03 12:00:16.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-helm/commit/0dc35f2efe64fc3cc57769a28710ed3a051bda60', 'message': "Mount volume in correct dir for Cinder state_path

Currently we're mounting Cinder's state volume in `/var/cache/cinder`.
This is wrong, as `state_path` option defaults to `/var/lib/cinder` [1].
Potentially this can be dangerous, as some of Cinder drivers (e.g. NFS)
are placing various volume information in that directory, and its
content should be retained during deployment upgrades.

This commit switches mount path of the state volume to `/var/lib/cinder`.

Closes-Bug: 1702072

[1] http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/cinder/tree/cinder/common/config.py?id=a688b8#n41

Change-Id: I03460151e01293b19a864528561c80cab1a72114
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2017-07-04 12:58:27.000000000', 'files': ['cinder/templates/deployment-volume.yaml', 'cinder/templates/deployment-backup.yaml', 'cinder/templates/deployment-api.yaml', 'cinder/templates/deployment-scheduler.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-helm/commit/ef62e93608273ecc69091255657594fad714a95a', 'message': "Remove /var/cache/cinder emptyDir volume

This patch removes unused `/var/cache/cinder` volume that is mounted for
each of Cinder services. I suppose it was added to serve as value of
`signing_dir` option from keystonemiddleware and is used to cache PKI
tokens. We're however never setting the option to that value and the
option was deprecated in Ocata, so we should be fine to remove it.

In case someone still wanted to use `signing_dir` config option, he can
easily confiure it back using config and volumes overrides.

Related-Bug: 1702072

Change-Id: I03460151e01293b19a864528561c80cab1a72114
"}]
commit_message:
Remove /var/cache/cinder emptyDir volume

This patch removes unused `/var/cache/cinder` volume that is mounted for
each of Cinder services. I suppose it was added to serve as value of
`signing_dir` option from keystonemiddleware and is used to cache PKI
tokens. We're however never setting the option to that value and the
option was deprecated in Ocata, so we should be fine to remove it.

In case someone still wanted to use `signing_dir` config option, he can
easily confiure it back using config and volumes overrides.

Related-Bug: 1702072

Change-Id: I03460151e01293b19a864528561c80cab1a72114
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-helm refs/changes/95/479795/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - name: pod-var-lib-cinder mountPath: /var/lib/cinder - name: pod-var-lib-cinder

subject: Enable oslo.cache for Neutron metadata agent
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-07-04 15:56:14.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/values.yaml', 'neutron/templates/configmap-etc.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-helm/commit/3d732ce4d0214f8b450e6c42b459cb65c85713a3', 'message': 'Enable oslo.cache for Neutron metadata agent

Neutron metadata agent can use oslo.cache to cache some requests to
neutron-server. As we have memcached already in place, we can enable
that feature. This commit does so.

Change-Id: I4ec1e7d22ed6bb54359dd5b6a80bc42222e59d00
'}]
commit_message:
Enable oslo.cache for Neutron metadata agent

Neutron metadata agent can use oslo.cache to cache some requests to
neutron-server. As we have memcached already in place, we can enable
that feature. This commit does so.

Change-Id: I4ec1e7d22ed6bb54359dd5b6a80bc42222e59d00
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-helm refs/changes/47/480247/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: {{- if empty .Values.conf.metadata_agent.cache.oslo.cache.memcache_servers -}} {{- tuple "oslo_cache" "internal" "memcache" . | include "helm-toolkit.endpoints.host_and_port_endpoint_uri_lookup" | set .Values.conf.metadata_agent.cache.oslo.cache "memcache_servers" | quote | trunc 0 -}} {{- end -}}

commit_message:
Fix html_last_updated_fmt for Python3

html_last_updated_fmt option is interpreted as a
byte string in python3, causing Sphinx build to break.
This patch makes it utf-8 string.

Change-Id: I502588bf0ce1fff0be34e9b21ef55be95d2d7bc1
Closes-Bug:#1693670
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/zaqar refs/changes/74/470674/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: html_last_updated_fmt = subprocess.check_output(git_cmd).decode('utf-8')

commit_message:
Support dot character in queue's name

Now Zaqar doesn't support '.' in queue name.
This feature will introduce the support for this.

Change-Id: Id698f043c0b1bc50567aba149e2235d9443bc105
Closes-Bug: #1695848
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/zaqar refs/changes/78/470878/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- features: - Support dot character in queue's name, like 'service.test_queue'.

commit_message:
Update subscription confirm doc

If users don't use devstack, message_pipeline will not be set by
default. Update the doc to remind users it.

Change-Id: I5f452778093c23d75a80e97961f1e359d558cc43
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/zaqar refs/changes/29/475629/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. note:: You should make sure that the message notification is enabled by your Zaqar. By default, the ``message_pipeline`` config option in [storage] section should be set like: message_pipeline = zaqar.notification.notifier

commit_message:
Install ansible-pacemaker on O->P upgrade

This has been omitted in Ocata image, so we need to install this in
O->P upgrade again. Change Ic8ce72133c47a4c90d581a0925213877b11a471e
adds it to the image, so that we can stop installing it on P->Q
upgrade, and start using it for minor updates too.

Change-Id: I893792e8d82c716b2f3e7b8878b25ba89ea724f1
Co-Authored-By: Marius Cornea <mcornea@redhat.com>
Partial-Bug: #1701208
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/30/478830/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: set -eu yum install -y ansible-pacemaker

commit_message:
Fix undercloud-upgrade job for Newton to Ocata

Several love fixes needed here:

- We forgot to override STABLE_RELEASE so
  the upgrade was failing because it was
  deploying repos from Pike instead of Ocata.

- Allow only to check that Ironic API is running
  on Newton or Ocata.
  In master we can check that ipmi driver is
  available.

- On old relases like Newton or Ocata we will
  use the old heat calls on get host info.

Change-Id: I558e86f5cec139cef165b0908bb3861434c7c8bc
Depends-On: Ie79dfff667437305ff4109da5a9c42ae358b1a3e

deleted_lines: # TODO: switch STABLE_RELEASE to ocata when released export STABLE_RELEASE=""

commit_message:
Add ZUUL_BRANCH branch to enable_plugin config

Add ZUUL_BRANCH branch to enable_plugin command in configuration. This
is in attempt to solve the gate failures here[1][2].

Patch with gate failures:
[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/438777/

commit_message:
Skip some bindeps for old Ubuntu releases

Ubuntu Precise and Trusty does not have packages listed
in bindep-fallback.txt:

  -- exclude liberasurecode-dev for Precise and Trusty
  -- add exclusion libjerasure-dev for Trusty

Change-Id: I07fb1eade0f12ae75ea0dfc48980ba91fa4d6908
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/45/452145/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: liberasurecode-dev [platform:dpkg !platform:ubuntu-precise !platform:ubuntu-trusty]libjerasure-dev [platform:ubuntu !platform:ubuntu-precise !platform:ubuntu-trusty]

commit_message:
Fix trusted host for NODEPOOL_PYPI_MIRROR

Incorrect trusted host is set in pip configuration when
NODEPOOL_PYPI_MIRROR is not placed on NODEPOOL_MIRROR_HOST.

To fix this issue it's need to derive host from NODEPOOL_PYPI_MIRROR.

Change-Id: I2c398dbe17bdcdf42ca1d317c3eae9a4231b8c3a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/23/336023/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: NODEPOOL_PYPI_HOST=${NODEPOOL_PYPI_MIRROR#*://} NODEPOOL_PYPI_HOST=${NODEPOOL_PYPI_HOST%%/*} trusted-host = $NODEPOOL_PYPI_HOST

commit_message:
Add spec for validator improvements

Change-Id: I06eebfdbdd1c5e667fef04182e81fb76c14add4c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/security-specs refs/changes/97/213997/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ====================================== Create well designed set of validators ====================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/anchor/+spec/validator-improvement Currently Anchor uses a set of validators which were created "as needed" during development. That means some are not entirely correct or make too many assumptions. A set of well designed validators should be implemented. Problem description =================== A number of the validators, especially those dealing with alternative names are not well designed. They make assumptions which are not valid and in general don't work the same way clients do when checking if the certificate is correct. Additionally there is no simple way to check "is this CSR valid according to standard rules". (rather than user-defined rules) This makes it possible for Anchor to sign requests which shouldn't really be allowed. Specific examples are: - `alternative_names` validator which relied on text descriptions as provided by openssl. This is not correct in all cases and doesn't work the way clients should interpret names. Officially those should be split into elements like DNS-ID and SRV-ID and when the operator configures Anchor, these are the elements which should be explicitly referred to. - Missing validator for CSR structure, like not enforcing NULL parameters for RSA encryption. Proposed change =============== A new set of validators should be created where missing. Badly designed original validators should be marked as deprecated. Additionally one larger validator should be created, which will enforce all rules related to the PKCS#10 and other relevant RFCs - these should not be user-specific, but rather verifying that the CSR is generally valid. Some of the possible things to validate in the CSR itself are: - no unknown OIDs in general name - no deprecated string types (Teletex, BMP, Universal) - invalid critical extensions (subject key identifier must not be critical) - all critical extensions are known - more than one CN entry (currently checked in unrelated code paths) - encryption/signature parameters - and others (grep RFCs for MUST/SHOULD) Validators which should be deprecated and replaced by new versions: - `alternative_names`, `alternative_names_ip` be replaced with validators that reference specifically IPs, DNS-IDs, URI-ID, or SRV-IDs instead - `server_group`, `blacklist_names` should iterate all IDs, instead of checking specific parts of CSR Validators which should be added to the system: - verifying CSR signatures - improving on extension filtering - both OIDs and names should be supported Alternatives ------------ Some of the proposed entries can be enforced instead of being checked. For example instead of approving only requests with known extensions, we can remove the non-critical unknown ones. Instead of rejecting invalid options, we can strip them. This solution is good for some situations, but not others - it should exist in Anchor, but as an option. That's part of the idea of fixups. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: stanislaw-pitucha Milestones ---------- Target Milestone for completion: Liberty-3 Work Items ---------- - add validators with proper domain name handling and deprecate `alternative_names*` - add validation of CSR against the standards - get feedback on what kind of custom validation is needed in the future Dependencies ============ - validator changes require either blueprint direct-asn1, or implementation of full extension parsing using cryptography.io References ========== * https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2986 * https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5280 * https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6125

commit_message:
Add Anchor spec for parsing backend change

Change-Id: I95826bd3410cace585ab29a8afd242f4314ec3c0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/security-specs refs/changes/28/205328/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================ Moving to direct ASN1 operations ================================ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/anchor/+spec/direct-asn1 The current implementation uses cryptography.io wrapper for parsing / crypto operations. This is not ideal for many reasons and a move to direct ASN.1 operations has many benefits. Problem description =================== Anchor needs the following two features currently provided by cryptography.io: - Certificate/csr parsing and modification - Certificate signing While the signing part is straightforward, the parsing and modification have many problems: - Any operation on strings / dates requires going through multiple levels of abstraction - python dates, python strings, asn1 strings, asn1 dates, and potential timezone conversions. This is currently not abstracted in cryptography.io to the level required by Anchor. Many of those operations are long and need error checking for openssl parts which shouldn't really ever fail. On the other hand, having the required ASN1 structures exposed as python classes reduces this issue to just a few lines of code with no failure conditions. - Operating on names requires attention to details, like how are all the names encoded. Rules for correctly replicating names using types different than utf8String are clear (even if complex) in the RFCs, but hard to figure out in OpenSSL (its API documentation is really poor and omits critical details). - Operating on extensions is close to impossible without relying on parsing / rewriting undocumented text representation of those extensions. While OpenSSL can expose the extension data itself, it would still need parsing ASN1. The common API uses text representation for all extension changes which is not only error prone, but also easy to abuse unless all possible error paths are handled correctly. Even then issues like embedded null bytes can cause confusion. - Memory management is hard in case of OpenSSL. Documentation rarely mentions explicitly which return values are pointers to existing data and which are copies. Some `..._free()` functions are no-ops for that reason causing even more confusion. Anchor freed memory which was being reused later for some time, before an unrelated change exposed the issue as a random test success / failure / SIGSEGV. - Right now, we run into the need for a new OpenSSL function quite often. Cryptography.io can't realistically expose all of them, but on the other hand we can't wait until new cryptography.io release every time we require new code. This results in Anchor getting more and more cffi code. While it may look like cryptography.io has nice abstractions for X509 which could be used here, they are not great for one main reason: there's no modification support at the moment and implementing it is not trivial and is subject to memory management bugs mentioned before. Proposed change =============== In order to do the signing correctly, we should change the local parsing / modification backend to something that can do pure ASN.1 operations. This has a lot of benefits: - Allows us to write code without ffi for most of the time. No complex more memory management and no useless error checking. - Allows us to preserve the some values from CSRs without a lot of extra work. For example if Anchor needs to handle some CA cert which uses BMPstring in the name, we can easily copy the whole structure, preserving all encoding information. - We can modify all elements in common ways. With `pyasn1` almost all operations can be coded in the same way dictionary interface works. This is not the case for OpenSSL. This also makes the code much simpler, while pyasn1 preserves ASN1 constraints on the values itself, so we won't accidentally create invalid structures. For example of how much better pyasn1 code is, here's creating an object from a parsed extension in cryptography.io code: def _build_basic_constraints(self, ext): bc_st = self._backend._lib.X509V3_EXT_d2i(ext) assert bc_st != self._backend._ffi.NULL basic_constraints = self._backend._ffi.cast( "BASIC_CONSTRAINTS *", bc_st ) basic_constraints = self._backend._ffi.gc( basic_constraints, self._backend._lib.BASIC_CONSTRAINTS_free ) # The byte representation of an ASN.1 boolean true is \xff. OpenSSL # chooses to just map this to its ordinal value, so true is 255 and # false is 0. ca = basic_constraints.ca == 255 if basic_constraints.pathlen == self._backend._ffi.NULL: path_length = None else: path_length = _asn1_integer_to_int( self._backend, basic_constraints.pathlen ) return x509.BasicConstraints(ca, path_length) While an equivalent with pyasn1 would be: def _build_basic_constraints(self, ext): ca = ext['cA'] path_length = ext['pathLenConstraint'] return x509.BasicConstraints(ca, path_length) Alternatives ------------ I don't see any good alternatives for parsing ASN.1. pyasn1 provides a good interface. It may not be trivial in all cases, but in general it provides a good and very explicit set of operations. While openssl could still be used here, pyasn1 provides pure python solution and a much better interface. Signing can be solved in many ways. My preferred solution would be pycrypto, which may be an old module, but it's stable and provides all needed elements (hashing, signing). Since it's only a few simple lines in Anchor, I don't think the library matters much. Another alternative would be letting cryptography.io do this part - it also provides the required functions, but it's much more recent. Basically any library which exposes PKCS#1 signatures and hashing is good enough. One benefit of using pycrypto is that it's very stable, while cryptography.io still happens to change interfaces and releases new versions frequently. Implementation ============== Some proof-of-concept code is already available in https://review.openstack.org/204368 Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: stanislaw-pitucha Milestones ---------- Target Milestone for completion: Liberty-1 Work Items ---------- - certificate and csr interfaces - DONE in PoC - signing - DONE in PoC - name interface (read) - DONE in PoC - name interface (editing) - extensions interface Dependencies ============ - requires including pyasn1 (already in global-requirements) - requires including pycrypto, cryptography.io, or other library (first two already in global-requirements) References ========== * https://review.openstack.org/204368
